td.p: Thomson, John. Journal, Mackenzie River, 1800-1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0021

div.p: would wait some of them for us along the River on the very spot where they wanted a Fort with plenty of Provissions &c – they likewise assured us that there was a Lake quite near to where they wanted the said Fort containing plenty of Fish, but it now appears that the said Lake is no less then 3 days March off – it is certainly very vexing to be thus imposed upon by such a set of Rascalls[.] The Indians that we embarked this morning for to Guide us – wanted us to put absolutely this evening ashore to Build, as he insisted upon it that there was no wood farther down but the other Young Men say that we will not arrive at the proper place untill to Morrow[.] Encamped at Dark not far from where the intended Fort is to be built[.]

Monday the 13th[.] Very cold. The y Man told us that the Fort was marked by his Parents and Piches, about 3 leagues further down on the left hand side of the River[.] [C]onsequently we went there, & just as we were going to put ashore, we espied a Smoke not far off[.] [W]e went to it & found it to be the Little Blind Chief & his Brother in law encamped in Two very miserable Lodges, remained sometime with them but could not get any satisfactory account from them as they have not seen they say any of their Countrymen since the middle of the summer[.] The former assures us that it is not on the left hand side of the River that his Parents & Piches appointd the Fort to be Built, but on the other side about a league back – there being none of that Stapple Comodity of Living Hares, on the left hand side the woods being there all Burnt &c[.] They have killed an orignal lately – took whatever Meat we could find about their Encampment – say for about the value of 12 sks difft Sorts[.] Returned back about a League, that is
